sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving gases
message_1: Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction 2H2(g) + O2(g) ⟶ 2H2O(g), given that the standard enthalpies of formation of H2(g), O2(g), and H2O(g) are 0 kJ/mol, 0 kJ/mol, and -242 kJ/mol, respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf°(products) - Σ ΔHf°(reactants)

where ΔH° is the standard enthalpy change, and ΔHf° is the standard enthalpy of formation.

For the given reaction:

2H2(g) + O2(g) ⟶ 2H2O(g)

ΔH° = [2 × ΔHf°(H2O(g))] - [2 × ΔHf°(H2(g)) + ΔHf°(O2(g))]

Since the standard enthalpies of formation of H2(g) and O2(g) are 0 kJ/mol:

ΔH° = [2 × (-242 kJ/mol)] - [2 × 0 kJ/mol + 0 kJ/mol]

ΔH° = -484 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -484 kJ/mol.
